author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: Hold On to Your Masks
description: Sales of face coverings have surged as the Delta variant spreads, and some designers see masks as permanent fixtures in our wardrobes.
content: When Elizabeth Schreiber, a registered nurse and mask seller in Boca Raton, Fla., saw mask sales on her Etsy shop surge in the last two weeks of July, she knew something was wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Megachurch Co-Founder Is Charged With Concealing Child Sexual Abuse
description: The Australian police alleged that Brian Houston, senior pastor at Hillsong, had failed to report assault by his father in the 1970s.
content: Brian Houston, co-founder and senior pastor of the global megachurch Hillsong, was charged by the Australian police on Thursday with concealing child sexual abuse carried out by his father in the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Yes, Lake Tahoe Chipmunks Have Bubonic Plague. But Don’t Worry (Too Much).
description: California officials closed some popular trails and nature areas for the week to handle the problem. The trails are expected to reopen for the weekend.
content: When California officials closed parts of South Lake Tahoe this week, the news sounded alarming: A dead chipmunk had tested positive for bubonic plague, the rare yet highly infectious bacterial disease responsible for killing millions of people in Europe during the Middle Ages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: YouTube Is Underwhelming
description: Even YouTube isn’t an unqualified financial winner. This does not speak well for the vitality of the internet.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Morse
title: U.S. broadcast coverage on Thursday morning includes skateboarding, baseball and basketball.
description: Also on tap: wrestling, water polo and cycling.
content: As the Tokyo Games hurtle toward their final weekend, there are plenty of semifinals and medal rounds on tap. Here are some highlights of the U.S. broadcast schedule on Thursday morning. All times are Eastern.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Whirlybird’ Review: Chasing a Story, From the Air
description: This documentary remembers the daring helicopter reporting of a couple in Los Angeles.
content: According to “Whirlybird,” a documentary directed by Matt Yoka, the sprawling freeways of Los Angeles — and the difficulties they posed for reaching breaking-news events quickly — prompted Zoey Tur, along with Marika Gerard, her wife and partner in journalism at the time, to start reporting from a helicopter. They were stringers, Marika explains, and always needed new videos. Cars didn’t cut it, especially once they became parents. There is harrowing, if retrospectively charming, footage in which their young daughter, Katy Tur, now an MSNBC anchor, assists while she accompanies them on a pursuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: A Milestone for Broadway as ‘Pass Over’ Begins Performances
description: The play is the first staged on Broadway since the pandemic-prompted shutdown, and is one of seven by Black writers planned this season.
content: Anne Grossman and Jennifer Rockwood hustled into Broadway’s August Wilson Theater shortly before 8 p.m. Wednesday and, beneath their face masks, smiled.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 11 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Other people’s relationships are catnip. You may think you’re above speculating about Bennifer 2.0 — are they really back together, or is this all a publicity stunt to pave the way for a “Gigli” sequel? — and, fine, you may in fact be above it; you’re here for books, after all, not for tawdry pop culture gossip. Might I recommend Michael Burlingame’s “An American Marriage: The Untold Story of Abraham Lincoln and Mary Todd”? It’s about somebody else’s relationship, and it’s educational. If you’re still in the mood to read about the mysteries of marriage when you’re done with that one, Anne Sebba’s biography of Ethel Rosenberg might fit the bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: How Cuomo and His Team Retaliated Against His Accusers
description: Governor Cuomo relied on a shrinking cadre of trusted advisers to guide strategy over sexual harassment allegations and to hit back at the women who accused him.
content: The governor’s inner circle was in a frenzy: A former state employee had just publicly accused Andrew M. Cuomo of a yearslong sexual harassment campaign against her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: How Do You Capture Four Decades of Hip-Hop? Very Broadly.
description: “The Smithsonian Anthology of Hip-Hop and Rap,” a 129-song boxed set, has a very challenging (and maybe impossible) goal: pinning down a constantly evolving genre.
content: In 1990, hip-hop was in the throes of an identity crisis. That summer, MC Hammer released “U Can’t Touch This,” his flashy, breakout single that, thanks to the flamboyant fashion and quick footwork in its video, became a pop music phenomenon. Hot on its heels a few months later was Vanilla Ice’s “Ice Ice Baby,” which sampled “Under Pressure” by Queen and David Bowie and became the first hip-hop single to top the Billboard Hot 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh
title: The head of the most powerful U.S. teachers’ union signals an openness to vaccine mandates.
description: “We are considering all alternatives, including looking at vaccine mandates,” Randi Weingarten said. Nearly 90 percent of teachers are already vaccinated.
content: The president of the most powerful U.S. teachers’ union signaled a growing openness to coronavirus vaccine mandates for teachers on Thursday, as the highly contagious Delta variant rips through the country and millions of unvaccinated children are about to return to the classroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ellen Barry
title: Boston’s mayor draws fire for condemning vaccine passports.
description: Kim Janey, the city’s acting mayor, said policies requiring proof of vaccination would unduly burden Black and Hispanic people.
content: Boston’s acting mayor, Kim Janey, made waves this week by comparing vaccine passports to racist policies that required Black people to show their identification papers. Her unscripted comments drew sharp criticism from her political rivals and from Mayor Bill DeBlasio of New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: A Ride to Space on Virgin Galactic? That’ll Be $450,000, Please.
description: The cost of a few minutes of weightlessness for new customers will be much higher than earlier prices, and they may have to wait awhile to fly.
content: If you were hoping to buy a ticket to space on one of Richard Branson’s Virgin Galactic space planes, you’ll probably wish you bought one seven years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: The White House makes a new push for students to get shots.
description: The White House hopes to use back-to-school physicals, pop-up clinics and other strategies to get more students inoculated.
content: The White House, worried that coronavirus vaccination rates among young people are lagging as the new school year approaches, unveiled on Thursday a new push to get students their shots, including enlisting pediatricians to incorporate vaccination into back-to-school sports physicals and encouraging schools to host their own vaccination clinics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Wolf
title: A Full House for an 82-Year-Old Hamlet
description: As England’s theaters welcome capacity audiences again, Ian McKellen is back in a role he first played a half-century ago.
content: LONDON — If you’re going to fully reopen a theater in these edgy times, it helps to have an actor whose presence feels like an event. That’s absolutely the case at the elegant Theater Royal in Windsor, England, where Ian McKellen, 82, is currently playing Hamlet, of all roles, and will stay on into the fall in a new production of Chekhov’s “The Cherry Orchard.” (“Hamlet” runs through Sept. 25.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Some school districts defy U.S. governors on mask rules.
description: School officials in Florida and Arizona say they intend to require students and teachers to wear masks in school, despite statewide bans on such policies.
content: New laws or executive orders in a number of states across the United States ban school officials from imposing mask mandates, leaving it up to parents to decide whether their children will wear masks in class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Steven Gardiner of the Bahamas wins the 400 meters.
description: Kirani James of Grenada won the bronze, the third Olympic medal in the country’s history. All three belong to James.
content: TOKYO — Steven Gardiner of the Bahamas emerged from a crowded pack to win the gold in the men’s 400 meters. Gardiner, who finished in 43.85 seconds, was challenged by Anthony Jose Zambrano of Colombia, who finished second, and Kirani James of Grenada in third. It was James’s third straight Olympic medal in the event: He won the gold in 2012 and the silver in 2016. Grenada has three Olympic medals in the country’s history, and they all belong to James.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Bix’ Review: A Jazz Legend Fondly Remembered
description: The composer and cornet player Bix Beiderbecke changed music forever in a very short life. A restored documentary from the ’80s goes into the details.
content: Although this iteration of this 1981 documentary is a restoration, one ought not go to see “Bix: ‘Ain’t None of Them Play Like Him Yet’” expecting a shiny cinematographic object. The movie looks like a 40-year-old mix of talking-head and archival footage. What makes it extraordinary is the story it tells of an uncanny musician and his beautiful playing and songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: ‘You Just Think About Eating’: Why Tunisians Backed a Presidential Power Grab
description: Dissatisfied by the government’s handling of the pandemic and the economy, some in this North African nation welcomed drastic action to change the political leadership.
content: TEBOURBA, Tunisia — Aroussi Mejri, a 40-year-old waiter, is lucky to have a regular job, even if it pays only about $7.20 a day. Yet although a lot has changed in Tunisia since he started working in cafes more than a decade ago, wages have not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: In Climbing, Finding a Way Up Is Just One of the Calculations
description: Because of a complicated scoring system, it was often hard to know who was ahead in this mash-up of climbing disciplines making its Olympic debut.
content: TOKYO — What no one predicted about sport climbing’s debut in the Olympics was just how compelling math can be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: The defection of a Belarus sprinter sheds light on a dictator’s control.
description: When Belarusian Olympic officials went to the sprinter Kristina Timanovskaya’s room after she complained publicly about her coaches, the head of the national team made it clear they had an order for her to return home — and it came from the top.
content: When Belarusian Olympic officials went to the sprinter Kristina Timanovskaya’s room after she complained publicly about her coaches, the head of the national team made it clear they had an order for her to return home — and it came from the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Texas High School Principal Sees Racism in Calls to Remove Intimate Photos
description: James Whitfield, a Black educator, said he was asked by his school district in 2019 to remove Facebook photos of himself and his wife, who is white, embracing on a beach.
content: In June 2019, shortly after James Whitfield, a Black educator, was hired as the principal of a middle school in Colleyville, Texas, an administrator with the school district called and asked him to take down photos on Facebook that showed him and his wife, who is white, embracing intimately on a beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: 50-kilometer racewalking strides off the Olympic stage.
description: The Olympic committee decided the race does not fit with the organization’s stated mission of gender equality because it is the only event that has no approximate equivalent for women.
content: TOKYO — Only the purest of the purists revel in 50-kilometer racewalking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devika Girish
title: ‘What We Left Unfinished’ Review: Spectres of History
description: For her first feature documentary, Mariam Ghani dug up five unfinished movies from the Communist era in Afghanistan.
content: In “What We Left Unfinished,” five movies started and then abandoned during Afghanistan’s Communist era, between 1978 and 1992, form a dazzling time capsule of the nation’s political and cultural history. The director Mariam Ghani — the daughter of Afghanistan’s current president, Ashraf Ghani — digs into the archives of Afghan Film, a state-run company that endured the whims and demands of various regimes before the Taliban destroyed most of its holdings in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Are We Finally Done With Tough-Guy Politicians?
description: Voters keep electing men with gruff demeanors and sharp elbows. And yet we are surprised when things end badly.
content: In the photomontage that accompanied his response to the New York State attorney general’s investigation into the sexual harassment claims against him, Gov. Andrew Cuomo aimed to portray himself as a misunderstood touch-aholic, a benevolent ingratiator who never met a rosy cheek he didn’t feel compelled to kiss, pinch or caress. Leaving aside whether these gestures were welcomed by their recipients, the bizarre slide show has him distributing his affections ecumenically — to wizened veterans and young children, to strangers, to Al Gore, to Robert De Niro — making the case that he who plants his lips on everyone by default violates no one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Was This a World Series Preview? Get the Popcorn Ready.
description: A two-game series between the Astros and the Dodgers drew more than 100,000 fans and quite a few novelty trash cans. Both teams walked away with heads held high.
content: LOS ANGELES — Bang, bang, the Houston Astros are not dead. Not buried. And much to the chagrin of the team’s numerous detractors, they are not even yesterday’s refuse.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Inside a Historic Economic Collapse in Lebanon
description: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, August 5, 2021.
content: “The best thing for us would be for some foreign country to come occupy us so we could have electricity, water and security.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikki Shaner-Bradford, Eleonore Condo, Gisela Williams and Alwa Cooper
title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
description: Ulla Johnson’s beauty routine, a film by Yael Bartana — and more.
content: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we’re eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Iran’s new hard-line president is sworn in.
content: Ebrahim Raisi, an extremely conservative cleric, was sworn in as president on Thursday, bringing to power a close ally of Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Bill Nunn’s Scouting Opened an N.F.L. Pipeline
description: Nunn helped turned the Steelers into a dynasty by welcoming players from historically Black colleges. As he is inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame the league still searches for paths to diversity.
content: This year’s Pro Football Hall of Fame induction will be led by the usual archetypes: Peyton Manning, the greatest passer of his generation; the standout receiver Calvin Johnson, known as Megatron; and safeties John Lynch and Charles Woodson, two of the best at their jobs in their day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: GOAL! Lloyd gets her second, and it’s 4-1.
description: Now it’s Australia’s turn for a defensive mistake.
content: Now it’s Australia’s turn for a defensive mistake.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Richard Trumka, A.F.L.-C.I.O. Chief, Dies at 72
description: A third-generation coal miner from Pennsylvania, he had led the labor federation since 2009, forging influential ties with leading Democrats.
content: Richard Trumka, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the nation’s pre-eminent labor federation, for the last 12 years and an influential voice in Democratic politics, died on Thursday. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: The First Debate in the Newsom Recall
description: A dispatch from Orange County, where four candidates vying to replace Gov. Gavin Newsom squared off in a debate.
content: YORBA LINDA — Last night was the first debate in the effort to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom, an election that could significantly reshape the future of California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ceylan Yeginsu
title: Cruise lines begin to impose more rules as a precaution against the Delta variant.
description: Most cruise lines are operating ships with at least 95 percent of passengers and crew vaccinated.
content: Cruise lines are imposing more stringent coronavirus measures as a precaution against the highly contagious Delta variant, which now accounts for more than 93 percent of cases in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Svoboda
title: An Athletic Coach for the Mind?
description: Part counselor, part strategist, mental skills trainers have helped pro competitors wrap their heads around success for decades.
content: When you imagine an Olympic athlete preparing for competition, you might picture them doing typical athlete things: running in place, stretching, making circles with their arms and wrists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Franklin
title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn, Manhattan and the Bronx
description: This week’s properties are in the Columbia Street Waterfront District, Midtown and Riverdale.
content: Click on the slide show to see this week’s featured properties:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fatima Faizi
title: Afghan War Casualty Report: August 2021
description: At least 115 Afghan security forces and 58 civilians were killed in Afghanistan in the first five days of August.
content: At least 115 Afghan security forces and 58 civilians were killed in the first five days of August. In a serious escalation of their campaign, the Taliban have laid siege in recent weeks to several provincial capitals after sweeping through much of the country’s rural areas. The insurgents now control more than half of the country’s 400-odd districts, according to some assessments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis and Megan Specia
title: In Photos: Fires Ravage Southern Europe
description: From the Greek islands to southern Turkey, extreme heat and dry conditions are driving devastating wildfires that have killed people and threatened homes, ancient heritage sites and tourist havens.
content: ATHENS — Shells of houses and cars left gutted by flames. Stretches of forest reduced to ash. Tourists evacuated by boat from once idyllic beaches where the skies are thick with smoke. As southern Europe grapples with one of its worst heat waves in decades, deadly forest fires have engulfed stretches of the region, bringing a newly reopened tourism industry to a halt and forcing mass evacuations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: As Taliban Advance, Biden Officials Cling to Hope for Afghan Peace
description: Taliban leaders and Afghan government negotiators still occasionally meet. But U.S. officials say prospects for a negotiated outcome appear to be fading fast.
content: WASHINGTON — As Taliban fighters make startlingly swift advances across Afghanistan, Biden administration officials continue to pin their hopes on a peace deal that would halt the country’s relentless violence with a power-sharing agreement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tommy Tomlinson
title: A Memoir of Pretending to See
description: In “Blind Man’s Bluff,” James Tate Hill opens up about the measures he took to avoid admitting that he had lost his eyesight.
content: BLIND MAN’S BLUFFBy James Tate Hill
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: First Guilty Plea Is Set in Jan. 6 Police Assault Case
description: Prosecutors are recommending a sentence of 41 to 51 months for the defendant, his lawyer said. The proposal may set a precedent for more than 100 people accused of attacking officers.
content: A New Jersey gym owner is set to plead guilty on Friday to assaulting a police officer during the storming of the Capitol in January, his lawyer said, the first time someone charged with attacking the police at the riot will accept responsibility for the crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: As Italian vaccine passports come into force, tiny San Marino is left isolated.
description: A microstate surrounded by Italy, San Marino turned to Russia and its Sputnik vaccine for protection. But European regulators have not approved the jab, making it difficult for recipients to take part in social life.
content: At the troubled beginning of Europe’s vaccine rollout, the Republic of San Marino found itself short on promised doses and turned to Russia for help. The tiny city-state, surrounded on all sides by Italy, quickly vaccinated most of its population with the Sputnik V vaccine, reaching levels of immunity that were the envy of larger European nations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below in the introductory article for this feature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: A bipartisan group of former health officials urge more safety rules in the private sector.
description: An open letter from the group recommends that private companies, which employ 124 million Americans, require staff to get vaccinated, and offers guidance if they choose not to.
content: A bipartisan group of officials from the past five presidential administrations, as well as public health experts, are pressing private sector leaders to adopt a new set of recommendations to maximize coronavirus vaccination among their employees.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 5, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Aug. 5, 2021.
content: An article on Saturday about the archaeologist Kisha Supernant misspelled the surname of the professor of archaeology who collaborates with her. He is Andrew Martindale, not Martin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Weise, Kate Kelly and Lananh Nguyen
title: Amazon pushes its return to office to January.
description: BlackRock and Wells Fargo also delayed their mandatory returns until October. Both attributed the changes to new developments in the spread of Covid-19.
content: More large corporations, including Amazon, BlackRock and Wells Fargo, announced on Thursday that they would delay their return-to-office plans as the spread of the Delta variant causes the number of coronavirus cases to climb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘The Viewing Booth’ Review: Do You See What I See?
description: One woman’s reactions to videos of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict are interrogated in this documentary by the filmmaker Ra’anan Alexandrowicz.
content: More than ever, moving images — body cameras that monitor police conduct, the video review of athletic event rulings — purport to capture the incontestable truth. But can the “evidence,” framed and reliant on human interpretation, truly force us to see eye to eye?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: My Son Died. How Can I Be Expected to Move On?
description: A reader asks for help dealing with pressure to put grief behind her after nine years of mourning.
content: My son died nine years ago from an opioid overdose. He was bipolar and trying to get on with his life after college, but he hit a rough patch, made some poor choices and was gone. I have gotten grief counseling, and I’m better. The problem is my stepchildren. In the middle of celebrations of big events in their lives — weddings, births, job promotions — I am often seized with grief that my son is not there and will never be doing these things. My habit has been to leave the events quietly and let my husband spend happy times with the kids. But recently, my stepdaughter told me that my sudden absences are casting a pall over their lives. They think it’s time for me to move beyond my grief. I am confused and hurt by this. Advice?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Guantánamo will step up testing of vaccinated visitors, following a rise in virus cases.
description: The testing is meant to forestall universal quarantining at the isolated U.S. naval base in Cuba, which would complicate upcoming hearings in terrorism cases.
content: WASHINGTON — The commander of the base at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, has decided to increase coronavirus testing of fully vaccinated people coming to the isolated base, rather than put them in a weeklong quarantine, following the discovery of seven virus cases at a time of heightened concern over the highly contagious Delta variant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard H. Thaler
title: More Than Nudges Are Needed to End the Pandemic
description: Persuading vaccine holdouts to get shots will require increasingly forceful interventions, a Nobel laureate says.
content: The only realistic end of the Covid-19 pandemic lies with widespread vaccinations, but a sizable part of the population doesn’t want them. A broad range of public responses is possible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: In a new ad, a Democratic group pointedly pushes Biden on voting rights and the filibuster.
description: The ad, aired by a major Democratic group, urges the president to support abolishing the filibuster so that Congress can pass federal legislation protecting voting rights.
content: A major Democratic nonprofit group is taking aim at President Biden in a new television ad, urging the president to take a more aggressive and concrete stand on overhauling the filibuster to pass federal voting legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Is the Future Just a Spike Protein Stamping on a Human Face, Forever?
description: The Covid endgame continues to elude us.
content: Last week, I wrote about the measures we may need to take to persuade the unvaccinated to sign up for shots. This week, I want to explore the other side of the question: How much danger does the Delta variant pose to the vaccinated? In particular, how does it compare with the seasonal flu?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Karate Gets Its Own Showcase at the Tokyo Games
description: The tournament is an acknowledgment of the martial art’s roots in Japan and a nod to its global stature.
content: Karate made its debut as an official Olympic sport at the Tokyo Games on Thursday as 120 men and women from around the world vied for medals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘Bring Your Own Brigade’ Review: Some Say the World Will End in Fire
description: In her new documentary, Lucy Walker looks at California’s apocalyptic fires and finds more than the usual smoke and politics.
content: A few times a year, I pull out our HEPA filter and begin reassuring worried friends and family members that, no, the city of Los Angeles, where I live, isn’t burning — or at least not yet. The air quality here is almost always poor, of course, but I tend to switch on the air filter only when the smoke comes, filling the basin and darkening the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: Stream These 12 Titles Before They Expire in August
description: Netflix in the United States is losing dozens of titles this month. These are the best among them.
content: There’s a little something for everyone in this month’s selection of titles leaving Netflix in the United States, including indie dramedies, family features and crime pictures, as well as the best of the recent James Bond flicks. Check out these 12 titles before they disappear. (Dates reflect the final day a title is available.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: Our critics and writers have selected noteworthy cultural events to experience virtually and in person in New York City.
content: It’s been almost 30 years since Damien Davis’s mother has read him a picture book. But she will do so again — while also entertaining a much younger crowd — on Saturday at noon at the Sugar Hill Children’s Museum of Art & Storytelling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Annette’ Review: Love Hurts
description: Adam Driver and Marion Cotillard are star-crossed lovers in this hallucinatory musical, written by Sparks and directed by Leos Carax.
content: “Annette” is a musical about the ill-starred romance between two artists, a description that suggests obvious kinship with “La La Land” and “A Star is Born.” Not to play algorithm or anything, but if you liked those movies, you will probably like this one too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: GOAL! Rapinoe gets her second.
description: Megan Rapinoe gets her second goal for the U.S. in the bronze medal game against Australia.
content: If you thought the olimpico was good, Rapinoe’s second goal was better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Russian Disinformation Targets Vaccines and the Biden Administration
description: A new campaign appears to be spreading falsehoods about the potential for forced inoculations against Covid-19.
content: The cartoon posted on the far-right discussion forum showed police officers wearing Biden-Harris campaign logos on bulletproof vests and battering down a door with a large syringe. A caption read in part, “In Biden’s America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Summer camps are canceled as Western wildfire smoke spreads.
description: We’re on top of the latest extreme weather in the U.S. and around the world. Follow here for news on heat waves, wildfires, floods and more.
content: Summer camps in eastern Washington State had to shut down this week after a stretch of unhealthy haze. Officials in Montana issued air quality warnings for nearly the entire state. And Denver residents were said to be comparing hazy conditions to the “brown cloud” that resulted from traffic pollution in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randal C. Archibold
title: Marathon swimmers battle heat and bacteria. Oh, and each other.
description: The swimmers knife a ragged line through the murky water and occasionally get hit by fish, until the end, when they thrash furiously to the finish.
content: TOKYO — They are among the Games’ earliest risers and some of its hardiest competitors, waking well before dawn for a race start at 6:30 a.m. that requires diving into a hot, polluted bay that one competitor likened to a “warm puddle.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Isacson
title: It’s Not Too Late for the Land of Mercenaries
description: The country is still working toward peace. It would be tragic if it became synonymous with a land of ex-soldiers for hire.
content: Take tens of thousands of former members of the military experienced in lethal tactics and skills, often provided by U.S. trainers. Give them meager pensions and little to do in an economy battered by the Covid-19 pandemic. Allow them — even encourage them — to sell their skills in a growing globalized market for security contractors and mercenaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: A New President Takes Office in Iran, Solidifying Hard-Line Control
description: President Ebrahim Raisi is a protégé of the supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, and his inauguration gives conservatives control of every part of Iran’s government.
content: Ebrahim Raisi was sworn into office as Iran’s new president on Thursday, consolidating the power of conservatives who now control all branches of the Islamic Republic’s government and are set to pursue a harder line in foreign and domestic policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick and Thomas Wright-Piersanti
title: Andrew Cuomo’s Political Future
description: His allies are calling on him to resign. Here’s why he might stay in office — and what happens next.
content: The pressure on Gov. Andrew Cuomo to resign is building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Gold Star Families Accuse Major Banks of Aiding Terrorists
description: A new lawsuit says the banks, including Deutsche Bank and Standard Chartered, ignored warnings that their customers were helping to finance attackers targeting Americans in Afghanistan.
content: Anne Smedinghoff, a Foreign Service officer at the U.S. Embassy in Kabul, was escorting Afghan journalists on an outing when a roadside bomb killed her in 2013. The bomb’s design relied on fertilizer made in Pakistan, at two factories that regularly supplied a nearby Taliban bomb-making operation — a fact that U.S. authorities had publicized.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nir Eyal
title: A ‘Quiet Zone’ Without Wi-Fi or Cellphones Should Be an Idyll. But Is It?
description: In his new book, Stephen Kurczy ventures to a town in West Virginia that is ostensibly off the electronic grid and he finds a more complicated reality.
content: THE QUIET ZONEUnraveling the Mystery of a Town Suspended in SilenceBy Stephen Kurczy
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Is Iran’s Supreme Leader Truly Supreme? Yes, but President Is No Mere Figurehead
description: Iran’s government is neither the democracy it claims nor the monolithic theocracy portrayed by critics. The new president, inaugurated Thursday, has real powers but is subservient to an “ultimate authority.”
content: An extremely conservative cleric was inaugurated as president of Iran on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The Relay Curse Continues for the U.S. Men
description: The sprint relay remains a mystery that the Americans cannot solve. The team failed to advance to the finals in Tokyo.
content: TOKYO — The disappointment for U.S. track and field, especially on the men’s side, continued in familiar fashion on Thursday, when four of the world’s fastest sprinters failed to qualify for the final of the 4x100-meter relay race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Oil producers used Facebook to counter President Biden’s clean energy message, a study shows.
description: Some of the biggest oil and gas producers and industry groups used Facebook ads to promote fossil fuels after Mr. Biden unveiled his climate change plan last year.
content: Soon after Joseph R. Biden Jr., then a presidential candidate, released his $2 trillion climate plan last year that promised to escalate the use of clean energy in the United States, the world’s major oil and gas dialed up their presence on Facebook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Day
title: Britney Spears Asks for Quick Hearing to Oust Her Father as Conservator
description: In a court filing on Thursday, a lawyer for the singer said that she would be harmed if her request to remove her father was left unheard until late September, as now scheduled.
content: A lawyer for Britney Spears has asked the court to accelerate the hearing on her request to remove her father, or to immediately suspend him, from the conservatorship that has controlled the 39-year-old singer’s life and finances for the last 13 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Baltimore Symphony Fires Flutist Who Shared Covid Conspiracy Theories
description: The musician, Emily Skala, who shared misinformation on social media, has vowed to challenge her dismissal.
content: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra said on Thursday that it had fired a musician who provoked controversy earlier this year when she shared Covid-19 conspiracy theories and other misinformation on social media.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Pattern & Decoration: A Movement That Still Has Legs
description: The first large look back at an irreverent style and its brief yet prescient life.
content: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y. — What is art history made of? Everything that happened within a given period, location or style? Or is it just the best of what happened? These questions form an eternal opposition between inclusiveness and quality. They crop up — and sometimes openly conflict — in “With Pleasure: Pattern and Decoration in American Art, 1972-85,” a rich, if flawed survey at the Hessel Museum of Art at Bard College.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Return to Work? Not With Child Care Still in Limbo, Some Parents Say.
description: The rise of the Delta variant and the uncertainty over schools and child care are keeping these parents from applying for jobs.
content: Brianna McCain left her job as an office manager when the pandemic started, to care for her two young daughters. By last spring, she was ready to go back to work. But she hasn’t been able to, because her children are still at home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: J.R. Richard, Fireballing Pitcher Whose Career Was Cut Short, Dies at 71
description: He was a star for the Astros and one of the most intimidating pitchers of the 1970s — until he had a stroke and collapsed at the Astrodome.
content: J.R. Richard, a flame-throwing right-handed pitcher whose scintillating career with the Houston Astros was cut short by a stroke in 1980, died on Wednesday. He was 71.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: In a key moment for the 2022 midterms, census redistricting data will arrive next week.
description: The release of the data, which is used to redraw congressional and state legislative boundaries, will set up a partisan fight over redistricting across the country.
content: After a lengthy delay, the Census Bureau will release the data used to redraw congressional and state legislative boundaries next Thursday, Aug. 12, the agency said in a statement, setting up what is certain to be a highly contentious nationwide fight over redistricting before the midterm elections next year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: School is back in session.
content: A number of public schools in Atlanta and its suburbs reopened today, ushering in the back-to-school season as the Delta variant surges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis and Megan Specia
title: Villages are evacuated and ancient sites under threat from fires ravaging Europe.
description: In Greece, firefighters tried to keep flames from reaching ancient Olympia, a UNESCO World Heritage site.
content: ATHENS — As southern Europe grapples with one of its worst heat waves in decades, deadly forest fires have engulfed stretches of the region, bringing tourism to a halt and forcing mass evacuations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Alyssa Lukpat
title: 10 Killed in Crash of Packed Van in South Texas
description: The vehicle was carrying 30 people believed to be migrants in Brooks County, about 80 miles north of the Mexico border, the authorities said.
content: At least 10 people died after a van carrying more than two dozen passengers believed to be migrants crashed on Wednesday in South Texas about 80 miles north of the Mexico border, the local authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: Alarmed Louisiana Residents Turn to Vaccines in ‘Darkest Days’ of Pandemic
description: Louisiana is leading the nation in an explosion of new cases. Hospitals are overflowing and admitting more young people than before. But the crisis is also driving some to get vaccinated.
content: HAMMOND, La. — Officials in Louisiana have been willing to try just about anything to jolt the state’s lagging Covid-19 vaccination rates, from a $1 million cash giveaway to a public service announcement featuring the recent 14-year-old national spelling bee champion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold, Jeffery C. Mays and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Sexual Harassment Report Spurs Quick Action on Cuomo Impeachment Inquiry
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and his lawyers were directed to submit any evidence in the governor’s defense to the Assembly by next Friday.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has been given until the end of next week to submit evidence in his defense for a wide-ranging State Assembly investigation that seems headed for a vote on the governor’s impeachment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Winkler
title: The Supreme Court Might Strike Down Biden’s Eviction Ban. It Shouldn’t.
description: By deciding the fate of the first  moratorium without giving any real reasons, the justices failed to do their job.
content: For months, millions of Americans, behind on their rent, have been living in legal limbo. This spring, a court struck down the nationwide eviction moratorium adopted by the Trump administration last September, ruling that the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention had overstepped its statutory authority. The case was appealed, and five justices of the Supreme Court signaled that they agreed with the lower court, but one of the five, Brett Kavanaugh, voted to allow the eviction freeze to stand — only because it was set to expire just a few weeks later, on July 31.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bonnie Wertheim
title: Shopping for Bathing Suits Online Is Its Own Circle of Hell
description: In theory, things should be easier with so many size accommodations.
content: Emily Ratajkowski designs her own. Kim Kardashian has hers custom-made. For pretty much everyone else, shopping for a bathing suit (online, at least) can feel a bit like walking through an endless hall of two-way mirrors: Nothing is as it appears, each of your steps is being watched, and no move brings you any closer to finding a garment that fits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: White House Makes Back-to-School Push for Student Vaccinations
description: With vaccination rates lagging among young people, the administration wants to incorporate vaccination into school sports physicals and is asking schools to host vaccine clinics.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House, worried that coronavirus vaccination rates among young people are lagging as the school year approaches, is enlisting pediatricians to incorporate vaccination into back-to-school sports physicals and encouraging schools to host their own vaccination clinics as part of a new push to get students their shots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Swan Song’ Review: Udo Kier, on His Own and Fabulous
description: In this drama from Todd Stephens, Kier plays an Ohio hairdresser who takes a long walk to do one last job — on a corpse.
content: The German-born actor Udo Kier has one of those faces that can turn from angelic to demonic in an instant. His eyes are in part heavenly lapis lazuli, in part impenetrable quartz. He’s an invariably uncanny presence. Directors who have hired him more than once include Paul Morrissey, Rainer Werner Fassbinder, Dario Argento, Lars von Trier, and S. Craig Zahler.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman and Evan Easterling
title: The U.S. bungles a baton handoff again and fails to reach the final in the men’s 4x100-meter relay.
description: Persistent baton trouble strikes again. The Americans placed sixth in their heat as they struggled with a handoff.
content: TOKYO — The United States failed to qualify for the final of the men’s 4x100-meter relay after bungling a baton transfer, yet again, and placing sixth in its heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘The Macaluso Sisters’ Review: Tragedy Across Time
description: This moving drama by the filmmaker Emma Dante imagines the ripple effects of a sister’s death across generations in Sicily.
content: No mere sun-kissed coming-of-age film, “The Macaluso Sisters” opens on a blissful day filled with young love and beachside longing that is tragically upended by an accident that has everlasting reverberations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Suhasini Raj
title: 9-Year-Old’s Death in Delhi Renews Protests Against Sexual Violence
description: Her family accuses four men of raping her, then killing her and quickly cremating the body to hide evidence. Demonstrators in the capital say it still happens all too often.
content: NEW DELHI — The grieving mother sat in protest on a busy road in India’s capital city and, undeterred by the heavy monsoon showers, repeated to anyone who would listen: Her only child, a 9-year-old girl, had gone out to fetch water from the cooler at the neighborhood crematory and ended up dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: When Men Are Accused of Sexual Misconduct, Women Become Political Cudgels
description: Defenders of Gov. Andrew Cuomo, Donald Trump and other politicians have often pointed to wrongdoing in the other party to deflect accusations of mistreating women.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: CNN fires three employees who went into the office unvaccinated.
description: The network has been relying on an honor system rather than requiring proof of vaccination status.
content: CNN said on Thursday that it had fired three employees who violated its coronavirus safety protocols by going to the office unvaccinated, one of the first known examples of a major American corporation’s terminating workers for ignoring a workplace vaccination mandate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Haxton and Reginald Dwayne Betts
title: Poem: A Cat Lover’s Guide to The Bell Curve
description: Brooks Haxton gives us poet as trickster.
content: From his new collection, “Mister Toebones,” Brooks Haxton gives us poet as trickster. And to be honest, I’m so tired of the bell curve and how it comes around like Halley’s comet every so often — but instead of bringing delight, it’s just a footnote to pedantic racism. Here, Haxton reminds me that there’s something spectacular in the caterwauling nine lives of a cat, and if that’s not an intelligence all its own, of course the tests don’t matter. Selected by Reginal Dwayne Betts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Luke Broadwater
title: Biden signs a bill awarding the Congressional Gold Medal to officers who responded to the Capitol riot.
description: Congress passed the bill this week amid reports of the suicides of two officers who had been at the Capitol on Jan. 6.
content: President Biden on Thursday signed a bill awarding the Congressional Gold Medal, the body’s highest expression of national appreciation, to a group of law enforcement officers who responded to the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: The Australian state of Victoria goes back into lockdown.
description: Just a week after emerging from its fifth coronavirus lockdown, the Australian state of Victoria reimposed restrictions on Thursday as officials tried to avert a prolonged outbreak of the Delta variant like the one seen in the country’s largest city, Sydney.
content: Just a week after emerging from its fifth coronavirus lockdown, the Australian state of Victoria reimposed restrictions on Thursday as officials tried to avert a prolonged outbreak of the Delta variant like the one seen in the country’s largest city, Sydney.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: NBC Tries to Salvage a Difficult Olympics
description: The pandemic has dimmed what is typically a festive television event, contributing to low ratings and complaints from advertisers.
content: The 1992 Olympics in Barcelona had the Dream Team. The 2008 Olympics in Beijing had the Michael Phelps medal sweep. The Tokyo Olympics has a pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: From Anthony Veasna So, Glimpses of Cambodian Life in California
description: The author set many of the stories in his posthumously published debut, “Afterparties,” in and around his native Stockton.
content: AFTERPARTIES Stories By Anthony Veasna So
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Nevin Harrison, 19, wins a rare U.S. gold medal in canoe sprint.
description: TOKYO — There aren’t many world-class canoers from the United States. There’s really just one.
content: TOKYO — There aren’t many world-class canoers from the United States. There’s really just one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Russia Bans Bard College, and Other Universities Ask What’s Next
description: Was it because of George Soros? Or geopolitical tension? Either way, the future of academic exchange could be in danger.
content: Bard College, known for its bucolic campus along the Hudson River in New York, its creative and freethinking spirit and its emphasis on the performing arts, now finds itself in a strange position: defending itself against the Russian government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Jessica Cheung, Michael Simon Johnson, Daniel Guillemette, Chelsea Daniel, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Dave Shaw, Rachel Quester, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The End of Andrew Cuomo?
description: An explosive report has detailed the New York governor’s sexual harassment of 11 women. What happens next?
content: This episode contains descriptions of sexual harassment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti and David Montgomery
title: Abbott Sets Up New Voting Showdown With Absentee Texas Democrats
description: Gov. Greg Abbott, a Republican, called a new special session of the State Legislature, putting pressure on Democratic lawmakers to return from Washington.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas on Thursday called a new special session of the Legislature that is set to begin on Saturday, renewing Republican efforts to overhaul the state’s elections and putting pressure on Democratic lawmakers who left the state for Washington last month to block the legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Hodgman
title: Judge John Hodgman on Supergroups
description: A couple argues about the most popular Traveling Wilbury.
content: Ted writes: While listening to “End of the Line,” by the Traveling Wilburys, my partner remarked, “It’s funny that their biggest hit doesn’t feature their most popular member: Bob Dylan.” I think that George Harrison is the most popular; she called him a “lesser Beatle.” Who is the most popular Wilbury?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Biden defers deportations of Hong Kong residents in the U.S.
description: President Biden said there were “compelling foreign policy reasons” for the order, which would give any resident of Hong Kong targeted for deportation an 18-month reprieve.
content: President Biden on Thursday granted special protections to Hong Kong residents in the United States, offering them a temporary deferral from deportation in response to an escalating crackdown by Chinese officials on democratic institutions and political dissent in Hong Kong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rainesford Stauffer and Abdullah Shihipar
title: Young People Do Not Need Shaming to Get Vaccinated
description: The  barriers young adults face are not inherent to their age, but they have fewer resources to tackle them.
content: Though young people in the United States are less likely to experience severe illness or death from the coronavirus, they’ve made substantial sacrifices to prevent its spread. They experienced disproportionate job loss and loss of loved ones. Many had to forgo traditional milestones of young adulthood, like graduations, proms and moving out on their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Europe is winding down its pandemic aid programs. Is it too soon?
description: Governments want vaccinations and a business rebound to carry the economy now, but cutting aid too quickly could create economic aftershocks.
content: After almost 18 months of relying on expensive emergency aid programs to support their economies through the pandemic, governments across Europe are scaling back some of these measures, counting on returning economic growth and the power of vaccines to carry the load from here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: J.J. Abrams is getting serious about U.F.O.s, and there’s still time to catch up on “The White Lotus.”
content: Every Monday and Friday, the Watching newsletter offers hyper-specific viewing recommendations. Read the latest picks below, and sign up for Watching here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: The steeplechase, like the horse race it’s named after, requires stamina, agility and grit.
description: Barriers and water jumps, not unlike those in the equine counterpart, make the steeplechase one of the most entertaining — and difficult — events in track and field.
content: One of the most entertaining — and difficult — events in track and field is the steeplechase, with its barriers and water jumps that are not unlike the ones in the horse race it is named after.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Murphy Marcos
title: Here’s what happened in the markets today.
description: Stocks rose in early trading, and the Labor Department said  jobless claims declined slightly last week.

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Washington Football Team Bans Native American Headdresses and Face Paint
description: The new dress code policy for home games comes just over a year after the team dropped its logo and “Redskins” from its name.
content: The Washington Football Team on Wednesday quietly announced that fans would not be allowed to wear Native American-inspired headdresses or face paint at its stadium.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Tim Arango
title: Justice Dept. to Investigate Phoenix Police
description: The inquiry will look at whether the police discriminate against minorities or mistreat homeless people or disabled people.
content: The Justice Department on Thursday announced a sweeping civil rights investigation into the Phoenix Police Department, marking the third such inquiry that the Biden administration has opened into abuse allegations against a major national police force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Bill Gates says his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein was ‘a huge mistake.’
description: “You know, there were lots of others in that same situation, but I made a mistake,” Mr. Gates told Anderson Cooper of CNN.
content: In an interview on CNN on Wednesday evening, Bill Gates acknowledged that his relationship with the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein was “a huge mistake,” and he told the host, Anderson Cooper, that his divorce, which became final this week, was “definitely a very sad milestone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Emily Cochrane
title: Infrastructure Bill Would Add $256 Billion to Deficit, Analysis Finds
description: Despite the Congressional Budget Office’s estimate that nearly half of the legislation would not be paid for, senators were racing to move ahead with it.
content: WASHINGTON — Republicans and Democrats rushed on Thursday to line up a Senate vote to pass the $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill, working to clear away the final obstacles despite a finding by Congress’s official scorekeeper that the bill would add more than $250 billion to the federal deficit over the next decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.J. Goldmann
title: ‘The Threepenny Opera,’ Without the ‘Cabaret’ Clichés
description: Don’t expect bowler hats and dirty negligees in a new production at the Berliner Ensemble, the theater Bertolt Brecht founded.
content: BERLIN — This winter, after live performances had made a modest return in Germany, the coronavirus pandemic brought them to another halt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘Vivo’ Review: A Musical Tale That Goes Offbeat
description: The animated musical, about a kinkajou who goes on a journey to deliver a song, may have an uneven story, but the movie’s stellar songs, by Lin-Manuel Miranda, reflect the artist at his best.
content: It’s all about the beat — in music and in “Vivo,” a new animated movie (streaming on Netflix) with an uneven story but dynamite songs from the “Hamilton” maestro himself, Lin-Manuel Miranda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: If You Name Your Book ‘Not a Happy Family,’ People Will Buy It
description: Shari Lapena’s latest thriller is on the hardcover fiction list, kids are in Halloween mode and other news from the world of best-sellerdom.
content: FLESH AND BLOOD Who wouldn’t be drawn to a book called “Not a Happy Family”? Shari Lapena’s novel makes an entrance on the hardcover fiction list at No. 3. Like the Canadian former lawyer/English teacher’s earlier best sellers — including “The Couple Next Door” and “The End of Her” — “Not a Happy Family” splashes into a stew of nightmares. “A wealthy older couple are found murdered in their home,” proclaims the novel’s 30-second trailer, viewable on Lapena’s website. “Was it a break-in gone wrong? Or did one of their children finally snap?” The music is “Jaws”-level stressful; the mansion flashing before your eyes makes the one in “The Conjuring” look like the Three Bears’ cottage. Lapena’s book has dark moments (“He’s been viciously stabbed many, many times, his fleshy throat slit”), but her dedication sounds a positive note: “To the heroes of the pandemic — the scientists, the medical personnel, the frontline workers everywhere — thank you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: A Crucial System of Ocean Currents Is Faltering, Research Suggests
description: A slowdown in the network, which influences weather far and wide, could spell trouble. “We’re poking a beast,” one expert said. “But we don’t really know the reaction we’ll cause.”
content: The water in the Atlantic is constantly circulating in a complex pattern that influences weather on several continents. And climate scientists have been asking a crucial question: Whether this vast system, which includes the Gulf Stream, is slowing down because of climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Senators rush to pass infrastructure bill as new analysis shows it would add $256 billion to deficit over the next decade.

content: Republicans and Democrats rushed on Thursday to line up a Senate vote to pass the $1 trillion bipartisan infrastructure bill, working to clear away the final obstacles despite a finding by Congress’s official scorekeeper that the bill would add more than $250 billion to the federal deficit over the next decade.

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Bucolic Beasts
description: Adam Wagner tells us a story.
content: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Unlike our print colleagues, the people who write online-only columns such as Wordplay do not have to worry about fitting our words into column inches, or whatever layout people are calling space measurements these days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Beware Remote Bias
description: As hybrid offices become the norm, remote workers risk being forgotten by management.
content: When companies fully reopen their offices, a large number plan to offer employees more flexibility over where they work. A “hybrid office” could make jobs more appealing and help attract and retain diverse candidates. But increasingly, companies are becoming aware of a potential challenge, DealBook’s Sarah Kessler writes for The Times: making sure remote workers don’t get left behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: The Biden Approach Is Working
description: There's a reason progressives keep losing Democratic primaries.
content: If Joe Biden stands for one idea, it is that our system can work. We live in a big, diverse country, but good leaders can bring people together across difference to do big things. In essence Biden is defending liberal democracy and the notion that you can’t govern a nation based on the premise that the other half of the country is irredeemably awful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Tokyo Olympians Are Showing That Grit Can Be Graceful
description: Simone Biles’s return. Competitors agreeing to a gold medal tie. A runner who fell but still won her race. The Tokyo Olympics have been a showcase for the beauty of resilience.
content: For all the controversy, for all the well-founded worry over hosting the Summer Games amid a pandemic that has killed four million globally and is currently lashing Japan, Olympic athletes have delivered again and again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King
title: The One Where It’s a Live Musical Parody of Your Favorite TV Show
description: “We made these musicals to get people who don’t go to musicals to go to musicals,” said a creator of the Off Broadway “Friends” and “The Office” parodies. “They’re a gateway drug.”
content: The titles of the songs in “Friends! The Musical Parody,” now playing at the Theater Center on West 50th Street, will be familiar to anyone with even a passing acquaintance with the sitcom about six coffee shop lingerers in New York. Joey sings an ode to the art of seduction entitled “How You Doin’?” Chandler and Monica’s amorous duet is “Could I Be Any More in Love With You?” There’s a song about adapting to challenging circumstances called “Pivot,” and, naturally, the post-interval number is “We Were on a Break.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘John and the Hole’ Review: Growing Pains
description: A young boy becomes obsessed with experiencing adult freedoms in this icy first feature.
content: “When do you stop being a kid?,” John (Charlie Shotwell), 13, asks his bemused mother (Jennifer Ehle) midway through Pascual Sisto’s “John and the Hole.” The question offers a key to this modern-day fable, one that John is dangerously fixated on answering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: In Praise of Smoke and Mirrors
description: If we need creative accounting to invest for the future, go for it.
content: America desperately needs to start investing in itself. And it can easily afford to do so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oskar Garcia
title: U.S. men are getting better boxing results, but they’re still chasing gold.
description: Duke Ragan of the United States lost to Albert Batyrgaziev of Russia in the featherweight gold medal bout. Two other Americans are still competing in their divisions.
content: TOKYO — Albert Batyrgaziev of Russia won the boxing featherweight gold medal on Thursday, and in the process stopped the first of three Americans trying to win gold in men’s boxing for the first time in 17 years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Continued Fallout From the Cuomo Report
description: The firestorm around Gov. Andrew Cuomo intensified as four prosecutors  announced criminal investigations and key allies withdrew support.

author: By Jenny Gross
title: ‘Jeopardy!’ Fans React to Latest Twist: ‘Who Is Mike Richards?’
description: Variety said Mr. Richards, the executive producer leading the search for a host to replace Alex Trebek, was now himself the top candidate. Sony Pictures Entertainment would not confirm the report.
content: The man in charge of engineering a successful “Jeopardy!” succession may have found the perfect candidate: himself.

author: By Debra Kamin
title: What if ‘Fauda’ Moved to New York?
description: Avi Issacharoff and Lior Raz, who created that Israeli hit, are back with “Hit & Run,” a new geopolitical thriller that swoops from Tel Aviv to the back alleys of New York City.
content: One afternoon in 2015, shortly after their gripping terrorism drama“Fauda” debuted in Israel, Avi Issacharoff and Lior Raz met for lunch in Tel Aviv.

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Aaliyah’s Music Will Finally Be Streaming. What Took So Long?
description: Twenty years after one of the most celebrated stars of ’90s R&B died in a plane crash, her songs — like “Try Again” and “If Your Girl Only Knew” — will be widely available.
content: For years, it has been one of music’s most conspicuous, and puzzling, absences: The majority of the catalog of Aaliyah, the groundbreaking R&B singer of the 1990s and early 2000s, has been absent from digital services — rendering the work of one of the most influential pop stars in recent decades largely invisible, and depriving her of a proper legacy. The singer, whose full name was Aaliyah Haughton, died in a plane crash in 2001 at age 22.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: A Rebirth in the Bronx: Is This How to Save Public Housing?
description: The Baychester Houses have been brightly refurbished using a federal program that could help fix America’s ailing subsidized housing situation.
content: Sandra Gross remembers moving in the 1990s into Baychester Houses in the Bronx. She gasped at her new sunny apartment and the flowers outside. “I wanted to kiss the ground, it was so beautiful,” she told me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Crouse
title: The Problem With Idealizing Olympian ‘Supermoms’
description: Cheer for these brave, determined mother-athletes — but also remember that they are succeeding despite the fact that society failed them.
content: We are happily drowning in American Olympian-mother success stories this year: After having a baby girl in January, Aliphine Tuliamuk will represent the United States in the Olympic marathon, alongside Sally Kipyego, who has two young daughters. When the sprinters Quanera Hayes and Allyson Felix qualified for the Olympics, they brought their toddlers onto the track to celebrate, and the moment was played and replayed on screens of all sizes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Sewell Chan of Los Angeles Times Will Lead Texas Tribune Newsroom
description: Mr. Chan, who became The Times’s editorial page editor last year, will be the editor in chief of The Texas Tribune starting Oct. 18.
content: The Texas Tribune on Thursday named Sewell Chan, a top editor at The Los Angeles Times, as its new editor in chief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis
title: ‘The Suicide Squad’ Review: Train Them! Excite Them! Arm Them!
description: The director James Gunn (“Guardians of the Galaxy”) shifts from Marvel to DC Comics with some familiar faces and the usual moves.
content: Joke, joke, kill, kill — that more or less sums up “The Suicide Squad,” the latest installment in the DC Comics franchise. Shiny, busy and self-satisfied to a fault, this chapter follows the comic-book movie template, now with 20 percent more gore. It also has enough cinematic allusions to give critics something to chew on. When the writer-director James Gunn is asked how he likes his steak, I am pretty sure he flashes on “Pulp Fiction” and, summoning up John Travolta at his suavest, says “Bloody as hell.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Elsie Chen
title: A Chinese gold medalist was asked about her ‘masculine’ appearance, prompting outrage.
description: Gong Lijiao, who won China’s first Olympic gold in the shot-put, was questioned on state-owned media about her life plans and whether she had a boyfriend.
content: After Gong Lijiao won China’s first gold medal in an Olympic field event on Sunday, a reporter for state news media asked about her “masculine” appearance and her life plans, setting off a heated debate about the restrictive discourse surrounding women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Ryan Crouser set an Olympic record. Then he did so again and again.

content: Ryan Crouser, the 2016 Olympic gold medalist, gave track and field fans a glimpse in June of what to expect at the Tokyo Games.

title: Biden Announces Record Amount of Climate Resilience Funding
description: The Federal Emergency Management Agency will give states $3.5 billion to prepare for disasters, as wildfires and other calamities pummel the country.
content: The Biden administration announced on Thursday a record injection of money to help communities gird against the effects of climate change, as disasters continue to pummel the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: To prepare for Tokyo’s weather, Belgium’s field hockey team trained in a heat chamber.
description: The second-ranked team, which faces Australia in the final on Thursday, created “heat-acclimation plans” for its athletes based on their risks of fatigue, illness or injury.

title: Messi’s Departure Is a Mess Everyone Could See Coming
description: F.C. Barcelona announced that league rules were forcing a breakup between Messi, the world’s greatest soccer player, and the club he has played for since he was 13. Could it really be that simple?
content: F.C. Barcelona cannot say it was not warned.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Maldives Knows Y.O.L.O.

content: “You can take that off,” Mandy Koh said, as I stepped off the speedboat and onto the pier of Lux North Male Atoll. “Guests don’t have to wear them on the island.”

title: Court Documents Identify Sailor Charged With Arson in Fire That Destroyed Ship

content: WASHINGTON — Investigators have identified the Navy sailor accused of starting a fire that engulfed the warship Bonhomme Richard and burned for days at a Navy base in San Diego last year.

title: U.S. basketball and volleyball play in their semifinals, and the 4x100 relay teams take to the track.

content: TOKYO — The American women’s basketball and volleyball teams have advanced to the semifinals. And standing in the way of gold medal chances for both teams on Friday is Serbia. The volleyball semifinal starts at 1 p.m. Tokyo time (midnight Eastern), with the basketball game 40 minutes later.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: A daunting number of virus cases.
content: The world recorded the 200 millionth detected case of coronavirus infection on Wednesday, a daunting figure that is more than the populations of Germany, France and Spain combined.

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Dividing lines harden as the Fed contemplates issuing a digital dollar.
description: Some Fed officials think the central bank needs to get in the digital currency game, while others fret about crowding out the private sector.
content: Officials at the Federal Reserve seem to be increasingly divided over whether it ought to issue a digital dollar — a digital currency that traces straight back to the central bank rather than to the private banking sector.

But while viewers will see smiling performers, sparkly suits and gelatin-slicked hair, a risk lurks beneath the surface: the potential for concussions.

title: The Best and Worst Cities to Flip Houses
description: And where not to try.
content: As home prices rise amid the booming real estate market, the opportunist in you may think that this is the time to buy, refurbish and sell a home for a neat profit. The average U.S. home flip in the first quarter of 2021 had $63,500 in gross profit, according to a recent study by WalletHub — not a shabby sum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Lightning Strike Kills 17 in Wedding Party in Bangladesh
description: More than a dozen people were injured, including the groom. The group was on its way to the bride’s house in a boat when the lightning struck.
content: DHAKA, Bangladesh — At least 17 people were killed and more than a dozen injured when lightning struck a wedding party on a boat in northwestern Bangladesh, officials said.

author: By Andrew Kaczynski
title: I Will Mourn My Daughter Forever. But I Was One of the Lucky Ones.
description: It’s hard enough to have a child with cancer. It shouldn’t crush families financially.
content: My infant daughter was diagnosed with a brain cancer nearly a year ago. She endured several surgeries and horrific side effects from her chemotherapy, which ultimately took her life on Christmas Eve. And yet, my family was one of the lucky ones.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Going for Broke in Cryptoland

content: They have names that make them sound delicious, like Cookie Coin. Or headed for outer space, like Pluto Coin. Or space-bound and delicious, like AstroCake, which was described this way: “Created 5 minutes ago. SAFE.”

title: New York Live Arts Announces Celebration Season
description: New work by Bill T. Jones, Colleen Thomas, Christopher Williams and Raja Feather Kelly will commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Manhattan arts center.
content: The coming season at New York Live Arts, announced Thursday, will include two important milestones: the 10th anniversary of the arts organization and the 40th anniversary of the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Company, its resident troupe.

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Apple’s iPhones Will Include New Tools to Flag Child Sexual Abuse
description: The changes, for later this year, raised concerns that the company is installing surveillance technology that governments could exploit.
content: Apple on Thursday unveiled changes to iPhones designed to catch cases of child sexual abuse, a move that is likely to please parents and the police but that was already worrying privacy watchdogs.

content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Thursday announced a multistep strategy aimed at rapidly shifting Americans from gasoline-powered cars and trucks toward electric vehicles — a central part of his plan to reduce the pollution that is heating the planet.

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘The Last Matinee’ Review: Killer Attractions
description: Set in a movie theater, this droll splatterfest is aimed straight at the jugular.
content: On a rainy evening in Montevideo in 1993, a hulking figure enters a shabby movie theater where the day’s final showing of a horror feature is about to begin. The auditorium is almost empty — a young couple here, some boisterous teens there — and, in the projection booth, a distracted student (Luciana Grasso) is subbing for her ailing father. An encounter between the ominous figure and a young boy results in a dreamlike shot of multicolored candy balls bouncing down a staircase — an image that will later be repeated, only with far more disgusting spherical objects.

author: By Robert Simonson
title: Views of 3 Boroughs, Complete With Cocktails
description: On Roosevelt Island, the Graduate hotel’s 18th-floor Panorama Room offers wide vistas of the city, and a new appreciation of its overlooked enclave.
content: Roosevelt Island, which perfectly but rather anonymously bisects the East River, has been home to a number of hospitals over the years. Soon, however, it will dispense a different kind of medicine.

title: The debate in Congress over presidential war powers will test a divided Republican Party.

content: YOKOHAMA, Japan — The Olympic gold medal in baseball, a sport absent from the Summer Games for 13 years, will come down to the two biggest baseball countries in the world: Japan and the United States.

title: Squirrel Acrobats Are as Smart as They Are Athletic
description: Picking a launch spot, sticking a landing, throwing in a little parkour and recovering from mistakes: Squirrels do it all.
content: Olympic gymnasts stun the world with their performances on the uneven bars. Fortunately they don’t have to compete with squirrels.

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Europe’s Pandemic Aid Is Winding Down. Is Now the Best Time?
description: Governments want vaccinations and a business rebound to carry the economy now, but cutting aid too quickly could create economic aftershocks.
content: PARIS — After almost 18 months of relying on expensive emergency aid programs to support their economies through the pandemic, governments across Europe are scaling back some of these measures, counting on burgeoning economic growth and the power of vaccines to carry the load from here.

title: U.S. Pushed for Olympic Skateboarding, but Came Up Short on Medals
description: Although skateboarding was invented in the United States, its medal haul was limited. And that was just fine by a sport proud of its international cast.

content: There’s a chill breeze blowing through Gagosian’s West 24th Street galleries this summer in the form of the group show “Social Works,” organized by Antwaun Sargent — curator, critic and author of “The New Black Vanguard: Photography Between Art and Fashion” — in his debut project as a Gagosian director.

author: By Jessica Cumberbatch Anderson
title: An Elegant Inwood Apartment Designed for Living and Working
description: The architect Christopher Rawlins moved into his Art Deco Manhattan building in 1999 and has used his space there as a laboratory for creating a sensual sort of Modernism.
content: One often hears that a home has “good bones.” The phrase is not typically applied to an entire neighborhood, but that’s exactly how the architect and historian Christopher Rawlins describes Manhattan’s Inwood, which, in addition to trains, parks and a vibrant immigrant presence, has one of the highest concentrations of Art Deco buildings in the United States, and is where he’s lived since 1999, when the area also appealed for its affordability. “You could practically reach into your pocket and pay cash for an apartment up here,” recalls Rawlins, who at the time was a few years out of graduate school and working at Alexander Gorlin Architects while also taking on the occasional teaching gig or independent commission. Today, he’s known for immortalizing the work of the 20th-century architect Horace Gifford with his 2013 book, “Fire Island Modernist,” and for his own reimaginings of midcentury styles and spaces — he recently completed a restoration of a late ’60s Harry Bates-designed home in Fire Island Pines. Moving uptown, says Rawlins, would allow him to reconceptualize his life. “I realized I didn’t have to be a cool kid in the Village and that, if I worked out of my home, I could call the shots professionally,” he says. And so he and his then-partner, the artist Tad Mike, purchased two units in the same 1935 cream brick co-op — a 700-square-foot one-bedroom to live in, and a 1,050-square-foot two-bedroom two floors below to use for their studios — and Rawlins launched his own practice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Paging Dr. Samantha Boardman, for My Mental Health
description: “Self-care is important,” the psychiatrist and wife of Aby Rosen told me. “But it can also be a slippery slope to narcissism, an excuse to push away friends.”
